content.body: Hi all
Just sumbitted patch, hopefully its the start of something great

Good morning annevk, some longish morning thought. I was thinking a lot about the fetch/timing integration. Maybe it was not right to associate the timing info with a response? A response is something that can be shared between fetches (service workers, cache), and would have different timing in each fetch context as some of the timing is measured before the response is created. Perhaps reporting the timing should be a method of the fetch instance rather than the response, and all the "attaching" is not necessary? Contemplating https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/issues/1208 and https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/issues/1215
content.formatted_body: Good morning annevk, some longish morning thought. I was thinking a lot about the fetch/timing integration. Maybe it was not right to associate the timing info with a response? A response is something that can be shared between fetches (service workers, cache), and would have different timing in each fetch context as some of the timing is measured before the response is created. Perhaps reporting the timing should be a method of the fetch instance rather than the response, and all the "attaching" is not necessary? Contemplating https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/issues/1208 and https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/issues/1215

content.body: yeah it was kind of long overdue
and for any given spec, itâ€™s not trivial to figure how to call into the Fetch algorithms in the right way
*for any given request scenario
trying to figure it out for multiple specs... For the CSS one it's a bit of a one-size-fits all because there are no load/error events, but still there are issues with referrers and CORS etc.
Noam Rosenthal: I guess conceptually you'd want fetch to return a response and timing info, but since the handshake is fetch(request) -> response it's hard to change that
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: I guess conceptually you'd want fetch to return a response and timing info, but since the handshake is fetch(request) -> response it's hard to change that

content.body: Noam Rosenthal: though maybe it's changeable more easily now that we have callbacks
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: though maybe it's changeable more easily now that we have callbacks

content.body: Noam Rosenthal: the other thing we probably still want to do at some point is FetchObserver (there's an issue if you search for this), which would also be a somewhat natural point to expose this on
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: the other thing we probably still want to do at some point is FetchObserver (there's an issue if you search for this), which would also be a somewhat natural point to expose this on

content.body: annevk: Fetch doesn't really return anything, but rather takes in callbacks that accept responses. I think that it could return some controller object that represents the fetch instance, which could have things like "report resource timing"
content.formatted_body: annevk: Fetch doesn't really return anything, but rather takes in callbacks that accept responses. I think that it could return some controller object that represents the fetch instance, which could have things like "report resource timing"

content.body: Noam Rosenthal: sure, I meant at a high-level, but yeah, at a concrete level I suspect we'd want to return the controller directly
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: sure, I meant at a high-level, but yeah, at a concrete level I suspect we'd want to return the controller directly

content.body: Noam Rosenthal: that would also give us a way to do abort more cleanly
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: that would also give us a way to do abort more cleanly

content.body: Noam Rosenthal: that's probably what I'd want to start with
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: that's probably what I'd want to start with

content.body: it would be easy to hook that return value into the fetch caller for the purposes of resource timing
We'd still want to use the timings of the callbacks to expose the information, though
I guess the idea of FetchObserver is conceptually that? I'll check the issue
yes, the callbacks will be there in the same way, but there will be no "attaching timing info to a response"
Noam Rosenthal: yeah, FetchObserver is/was for progress events and HTTP/2 push, but the latter died and there was never enough interest in the former (and it can be polyfilled using streams)
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: yeah, FetchObserver is/was for progress events and HTTP/2 push, but the latter died and there was never enough interest in the former (and it can be polyfilled using streams)

content.body: Yeah, we'd attach it to the controller
I think the controller will have access to the fetch params
like a public facade for stuff you can do with things from the fetch params
Yeah, I think we'd want a facade of sorts (or asserts) to ensure specs don't do weird things
Great, let me jot down something

this would also make it possible to update resource timing entries after they're created, e.g. if in the future we would want to spec that a `video` resource timing entry is created when the response is ready but updated with its `responseEnd` when it's done
content.formatted_body: this would also make it possible to update resource timing entries after they're created, e.g. if in the future we would want to spec that a video resource timing entry is created when the response is ready but updated with its responseEnd when it's done

content.body: Noam Rosenthal: I think in principle that should be possible either way, but this might make it easier
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: I think in principle that should be possible either way, but this might make it easier

content.body: yea exactly

Noam Rosenthal: now that you mention it though, how do we account for media elements currently? They always make range requests so they get responses quite quickly. The spec for them doesn't quite reflect this (or at least not in sufficient detail)
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: now that you mention it though, how do we account for media elements currently? They always make range requests so they get responses quite quickly. The spec for them doesn't quite reflect this (or at least not in sufficient detail)

content.body: I guess the current setup might end up with an entry per range request potentially?
annevk: currently in the spec, that integration is not done yet. I need to research how it's done in implementations. I wanted to have a good infrastructure with the simpler requests first
content.formatted_body: annevk: currently in the spec, that integration is not done yet. I need to research how it's done in implementations. I wanted to have a good infrastructure with the simpler requests first

content.body: annevk: https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/pull/1329
content.formatted_body: annevk: https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/pull/1329

content.body: annevk: btw, I think also `cacheState` and `timing allow passed flag` should be associated with a fetch and not with a response, for the same reasons. It's not clear how they're forwarded from service workers or restored from cache
content.formatted_body: annevk: btw, I think also cacheState and timing allow passed flag should be associated with a fetch and not with a response, for the same reasons. It's not clear how they're forwarded from service workers or restored from cache

content.body: By restored from cache you mean restored from the Cache API? That might make sense. There's a general issue with that API not getting as much attention as it deserves.

annevk: I meant also from HTTP cache. It's not spec`ed how those responses are stored, and as far as the spec is concerned the response stored in the cache is a reference to the same one that's restored.
content.formatted_body: annevk: I meant also from HTTP cache. It's not spec`ed how those responses are stored, and as far as the spec is concerned the response stored in the cache is a reference to the same one that's restored.

content.body: Noam Rosenthal: well, but we always set this field when we pull something from the cache
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: well, but we always set this field when we pull something from the cache

content.body: annevk: right, but we set it *on the response*, which could mean setting it on the original response also. I think there is a related Chrome bug about exactly this
content.formatted_body: annevk: right, but we set it on the response, which could mean setting it on the original response also. I think there is a related Chrome bug about exactly this

content.body: e.g. if you store a response to cache and retrieve it before it's done, both responses would get the same cacheState
I think I'm missing how it's observable
Aah
Presumably we should take a copy when storing it in the cache (or take a copy when forwarding).
In theory that also seems problematic for reading the body for instance (which can only happen once).
yes, and I added a non-normative note as such
Ah actually it was something else, got mixed up
It's presumably a copy, but it's not formally a copy, and there is no definition of what a "response copy" is
which, I believe, fudges some things in existing implementations when response objects are shared between fetches
Hmm, how did https://twitter.com/htmlstandard/status/1447820555760005122 get tweeted?
Ah, I forgot to remove a leading space when squashing. Good times.
annevk: updated the PR, now timing/TAO/cacheState are all part of fetch params and accessible through a controller. Regarding `body` I'll open a separate issue, I'm less familiar with it.
content.formatted_body: annevk: updated the PR, now timing/TAO/cacheState are all part of fetch params and accessible through a controller. Regarding body I'll open a separate issue, I'm less familiar with it.

content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: note that if you're moving cacheState we'll need to update SW too

content.body: Actually, this might be more complex... not sure if on some cases RT users rely on  resource-timing being per response rather than per-fetch, need to clarify with the working group

content.body: annevk: : I mean, for example, when a service worker forwards a network response. Should the connection info be available only inside the context of the service worker, or should it be part of the resource entry of the document? Same for resources that were fetched early in the document and then accessed from cache.
content.formatted_body: annevk: : I mean, for example, when a service worker forwards a network response. Should the connection info be available only inside the context of the service worker, or should it be part of the resource entry of the document? Same for resources that were fetched early in the document and then accessed from cache.

content.body: I personally believe the cleanest solution that doesn't lose any info would be that a Resource Timing Entry is mapped 1:1 to a fetch, but I have to see with the WG whether there are other expectations or existing implementations that counter this
Noam Rosenthal: I thought we had some forwarding of service worker data already?
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: I thought we had some forwarding of service worker data already?

content.body: annevk: the service worker timing info itself is extra information available to navigations. What we forward from the service worker for non-navigation resources is a response. Since that forwarding happens before fetch-finale, that response's timing info gets overwritten by the document's fetch
content.formatted_body: annevk: the service worker timing info itself is extra information available to navigations. What we forward from the service worker for non-navigation resources is a response. Since that forwarding happens before fetch-finale, that response's timing info gets overwritten by the document's fetch

content.body: I see, there is some complexity there as some service worker responses might not yet carry timing info, so any change would have to be considered carefully
annevk: are "flags" in the fetch spec considered atomic? I didn't see information about this in `infra`
content.formatted_body: annevk: are "flags" in the fetch spec considered atomic? I didn't see information about this in infra

content.body: Noam Rosenthal: no, jyasskin has brought this up here and there and Jake Archibald too. Saying it's atomic when using it is probably sufficient for now.
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: no, jyasskin has brought this up here and there and Jake Archibald too. Saying it's atomic when using it is probably sufficient for now.

content.body: Ok, so something like "atomically test and set" this or that.
